Segregation of K and its effects on the growth, decoration, and adsorption properties of Rh nanoparticles on TiO2(110) András Berkó a b Nándor Balázs a György Kassab b László Óvári a ⁎ a Reaction Kinetics Research Laboratory, Institute of Nanochemistry and Catalysis, Chemical Research Center of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences, H-6720 Szeged, Dóm tér 7, Hungary b Department of Physical Chemistry and Material Science, University of Szeged, H-6720 Szeged, Aradi vértanúk tere 1, Hungary ⁎ Corresponding author. Address: P.O. Box 168, H-6701 Szeged, Hungary. Fax: +36 62 544 106. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Partially oxidized K clusters (1–2nm) were formed on TiO2(110) by segregation. ► Rh nucleated and grown with strong preference on K-free TiO2 regions. ► Nevertheless, electrons are transferred from K to Rh, probably through TiO2. ► This indirect electron transfer leads to a stabilization of CO bound to Rh. ► A TiO x decoration layer, containing no K, is formed on Rh clusters upon annealing. In order to understand the promoting mechanism of alkali additives, we have studied potassium overlayers on TiO2(110). The surface was prepared by thermal segregation of K from the bulk to the surface above 750–800K. The bulk diffusion of the Ti/O ions is required for the migration of large K ions inside the lattice. STM and LEIS revealed that segregated potassium forms small clusters of 1–2nm on the surface, containing also oxygen. These clusters are located preferentially on the one-dimensional defect sites (Ti2O3 strings) of the (1×1) rutile surface and on the Ti2O3 rows of the (1× n) reconstructed surfaces. According to XPS, the potassium on the surface after segregation at 1000K is only partially ionized and the Ti 2p region is dominated by the Ti4+ component. XPS and LEIS provided evidence of a very clear preference for the Rh clusters to grow near 300K not on the potassium structures but on the potassium-free parts of titania surface. This finding may imply the absence of a direct contact between Rh and K at low Rh coverages. Nevertheless, evaporation of Rh on K/TiO2(110) results in more cationic K sites, due to an electron transfer from K to Rh through titania. The decoration and encapsulation of Rh nanoparticles by TiO x proceed also in the presence of potassium. The capping layer does not contain potassium. At large Rh cluster sizes, the wheel-like structure of the cover layer could be identified with a structure found on top of Rh crystallites formed on the K-free titania surface. The presence of potassium stabilized CO on Rh nanoparticles, which is attributed to the indirect charge transfer from potassium structures to rhodium (long range effect). Keywords Alkali promoter Potassium segregation Rhodium Strong metal support interaction TiO2(110) XPS STM LEIS 1 Introduction Alkali additives are extensively applied as promoters in heterogeneous catalysis, like in ammonia synthesis, ethylene epoxidation, Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS), alcohol synthesis, water–gas shift reaction (WGS), and also in gas sensors [1–3]. In order to shed light on the mechanism of alkali promotion, the interaction of alkali atoms with well-defined metal single crystal surfaces, and the adsorption and reactions of various compounds on alkali covered surfaces were thoroughly investigated [4–9]. In order to mimic more accurately the morphology of real catalysts, to bridge the so-called “material gap”, two-dimensional model catalysts can be prepared depositing metals on single crystalline oxide surfaces, and the structure and reactivity can be revealed by the wide arsenal of surface science both at low and high pressures [10–16]. Accordingly, an increasing number of studies has been reported on the interaction of alkali with oxide surfaces [10–12], but in surprisingly few cases also in the presence of a catalytically active metal [17,18]. In a previous study of ours, we have shown that surface potassium significantly affects the morphology (average size and distribution) of Au nanoparticles on TiO2(110) [17]. In the model experiments related to alkali promotion, the deposition of alkali metals characteristically resulted in a substantial decrease in the work function both on metal and on oxide single crystal surfaces, and also in some band bending for oxides [4–10]. The bonding with titania is highly cationic at small alkali coverages (Θ K ∼1/4–1/2ML, where 1ML is defined as one alkali site per surface unit cell of titania), due to an electron transfer from the alkali atom to TiO2, while depolarization occurs approaching Θ K =1ML due to the repulsive interactions among neighboring dipoles. Accordingly, a dramatic broadening of thermal desorption features toward lower temperatures was experienced at higher alkali coverages (still below 1ML) [10]. These characteristics are similar to what was found for alkali adsorption on metal surfaces [4,5]. As regards the binding sites, surface extended X-ray fine structure (SEXAFS) analysis indicated that potassium atoms/ions are bonded to oxygen sites with an inclined bridge or threefold hollow geometry on rutile TiO2(100) and TiO2(110) surfaces [19,20]. Interestingly, according to scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) and atomic force microscopy (AFM) studies, the repulsive interaction among neighboring K ions cannot prevent the formation of K covered islands, or one-dimensional condensed structures [17,20,21]. It suggests that the electronic and structural effects combine strongly and it should be taken into account during the interpretation of any special phenomenon related to alkali additives. Unlike on metal surfaces, alkali metal adsorption on oxides may result in a redox reaction leading to the reduction of the substrate, as was observed for K on Fe3O4(111) [22], K on NiO(100) [10], Na on TiO2(110) [11], and for many other systems. In photoemission studies, the appearance of reduced Ti3+ (and even Ti2+) sites was detected due to K deposition on titania, as well as the occupation of Ti 3d states in the band gap of TiO2 [19,23]. According to calculations, the transferred charge is delocalized among the adjacent Ti ions [24,25]. Photoemission results related to the thermal behavior showed that the surface concentration of reduced Ti sites almost disappeared after high temperature annealing (1020K), even when the coverage was still as high as Θ K =0.5ML [25,26]. In contrary to most model experiments, where alkali atoms were evaporated onto the sample, during the preparation of realistic polycrystalline catalysts, the alkali component is added to the slurry in the form of ionic compounds. Of course, in that way, the reduction of the support oxide, which certainly influences its reactivity, does not necessarily proceed. The potassium overlayer is prepared in this study not by evaporation, but by thermal segregation of potassium from rutile TiO2(110) crystals. Note that potassium contamination is very probably of ionic nature within the bulk of titania crystals. The segregation of K from titania was investigated only in one previous study, using a TiO2(100) crystal [27]. The accumulation of potassium in the outermost atomic layer of the surface was observed at 675K and above. At 975K, however, no potassium was detected on the topmost atomic layer, but was still present in the sampling depth of Auger electron spectroscopy (AES). The segregation of Ca to TiO2(110) produces a rather smooth, well-ordered overlayer [28], indicating that Ca remains in intimate contact with the substrate. Based on calculations, a significantly relaxed, complex surface structure was proposed, which was not assigned to bulk like CaO or to any of the bulk calcium titanates [28]. For the understanding of alkali promotion, it is a key issue to disclose, whether the alkali additive is located on the metal or on the support, and to identify its chemical nature. Accordingly, we investigated the nucleation and growth of Rh on a potassium-covered TiO2(110). Beside structural properties, charge transfer processes are also of outmost importance in catalytic promotion. The results related to this latter aspect are presented as well. It is well established that due to reduction in H2 atmosphere, a TiO x capping layer is formed on Ni, Pd, Rh, Ir, and Pt clusters supported by TiO2, which is a key factor in the so-called Strong Metal Support Interaction (SMSI) [12,29,30]. The encapsulation of the clusters of these metals by TiO x proceeds in vacuum even in the absence of H2, if the TiO2 sample is sufficiently reduced [31–34]. It is an important question, how the presence of an alkali influences this process. In the previous studies related to high surface area powder materials, it was assumed that the presence of potassium significantly facilitates the decoration process through the formation of potassium hydroxides and titanates [35]. This point is analyzed also in the present paper. 2 Experimental The experiments were carried out in two different UHV systems evacuated down to 5×10−8 Pa. 1. The first one (denoted as the XPS-LEIS chamber) was equipped with a hemispherical analyzer (Leybold EA10/100) for performing low-energy ion scattering (LEIS), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and AES measurements. A quadrupole mass spectrometer was also built in for thermal desorption spectroscopy (TDS). For LEIS, He ions of 760eV kinetic energy were applied (0.03μA/cm2), while the scattering angle was 95°. Note that LEIS supplies information almost exclusively about the outermost atomic layer, when performed with noble gas ions. An Al Kα X-ray source was applied for XPS. The binding energy scale was referenced to the 4f7/2 peak of a thick Au layer, fixed at 83.8eV. The pass energy was typically 100eV, but for the Auger parameter analysis 10eV. If not mentioned otherwise, the take-off angle (θ) was 16°, with respect to surface normal. The X-ray satellites at 9.8 and 11.8eV away from the main lines were removed in the Ti 2p, K 2p, and Rh 3d regions by subtracting the given spectrum after scaling and x-shifting, taking into account that the respective intensities are 6.4% and 3.2% of the main intensities [36]. For the O 1s region, this procedure was not necessary, because the influence of X-ray satellites on the peaks was negligible. CO (99.97% purity) was dosed through a capillary. During TDS measurements, the sample was in line of sight and the heating rate was 1Ks−1. 2. In the second UHV chamber (denoted as the STM chamber), a commercial room temperature STM (WA-Technology) and a cylindrical mirror analyzer with a central electron gun (Staib-DESA-100) for AES were built in. For STM imaging, chemically edged IrPt or W tips were applied and sharpened “in situ” over the TiO2 surface by using 5–10V pulses. Typical tunneling parameter of +3V (0.1nA) was applied due to the relatively high band gap of the overlayer. In the case of clean surface, the imaging bias of +1.5V proved to be sufficient. In both chambers, rutile TiO2(110) single crystals of the same manufacturer were applied, and the probe temperature was measured by a chromel–alumel (K-type) thermocouple stuck to the side of the samples by a UHV compatible oxide adhesive (Ceramobond 569, Aremco). The probes were resistively heated (1–2Ks−1) with a Ta filament. The samples were routinely cleaned applying Ar+ ion sputtering (10μAcm−2, 1.5keV, 10min, 300K) and vacuum annealing (10min, 1000–1050K) cycles. After a short annealing at 1050K in UHV, the surface of the TiO2(110) probe obtained in this way exhibited mainly (1×1) ordered phase accompanied by some (3–5% of the total surface area) protruding dots and 1D stripes in the [001] orientation [37]. The potassium overlayer in this work was prepared by thermal segregation. Generally, the potassium content of a TiO2 crystal is exhausted by 30–50 sputtering–annealing cycles. This was the case for the samples studied in the STM chamber, and for this reason, several samples had to be used to perform the experiments. On the other hand, for the sample investigated in the XPS-LEIS chamber, the K coverage obtained by 5–10min annealing at 1000K was stable during the period of the experiments (∼3month), characterized by a K/Ti AES ratio of R K =0.9, obtained from the peak-to-peak intensities of the main KLMM (252eV) and TiLMM (385eV) peaks in the differential mode. Other typical impurities (Ca, Mg, Na) were not present in the samples. The coverage of potassium is defined in this work as the number of surface potassium atoms/ions per unit cell area of the unreconstructed TiO2(110) surface (1ML∼5.20×1014 cm−2). In the STM chamber, potassium coverage was determined from R K ratios [21]. In the XPS-LEIS chamber, K coverage was determined from XPS peak areas applying photoelectric cross-sections and inelastic-mean-free-path (imfp) values of Scofield [38] and Seah and Dench [39]. At R K =0.9, the potassium coverage calculated this way was 0.9ML. It was assumed that the same R K AES ratios in the different chambers corresponded to comparable coverages, using Auger spectra collected with the same primary energy (3keV) and with constant pass energy in both systems. Rh was deposited by a commercial 4-pocket PVD source (Oxford Applied Research) using a high-purity (99.95%) Rh rod. The coverage of Rh is expressed in equivalent monolayers, defined as the surface concentration of Rh(111) (1ML∼1.60×1015 cm−2). Rh coverage was determined in the XPS-LEIS chamber based on XPS peak areas [38,39]. The evaporation rate was 0.25ML/min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Segregation of potassium on the TiO2(110) surface 3.1.1 Main features of the segregation process of potassium on TiO2(110) It is our long-term experience with different TiO2(110) single crystals purchased commercially that a better quality orientation (appearance of large atomic terraces detected by STM from the beginning of the cleaning) usually connects to a faster exhaustion of the subsurface contaminations (mainly K and some Ca) and to a smaller amount of K appearing upon annealing. This property may refer to an enhanced segregation at the step sites. In order to follow the exhaustion of the K contamination, we started from a new crystal and used the same treatments: 10min Ar+ bombardment at room temperature (1.5keV, ∼10−5 Acm−2) followed by 10min annealing at 1050K in UHV. In the case of a sample exhibiting large atomic terraces and presented in Fig. 1 , and 3–5 cycles were sufficient to achieve a traceable decrease in the amount of segregated potassium (down to app. R K =0.2). Further 5–10 cycles resulted in a remarkable fall of R K value (down to app. 0.05) detectable after the annealing. At this level of surface potassium, in some cases, it totally disappeared after a few further cleaning treatments, but it could reappear again at a detectable level (R K >0.02). For the characterization of the extent of the thermally activated K segregation, a freshly ion sputtered surface was annealed at stepwise increased temperatures for 10min (and cooled back to RT for AES detection, Fig. 1A). The relative Auger intensities (R K) are plotted as a function of the temperature for a sample at two different levels of cleanliness: curve (i) concerns a sample just at the beginning of the cleaning, curve (ii) refers to a sample after 4 cleaning cycles. For both curves, the onset temperature of K appearance is about 700–800K, below which no potassium was detected on the ion sputtered TiO2(110) surface. Further increase in the temperature resulted in an enhancement of surface potassium concentration. Annealing at 1050K did not cause any additional increase in K coverage. STM images were recorded on the samples at three different K contamination levels after annealing at 1050K (Fig. 1B–G). At R K =0.24, the surface is totally covered by small dots and islands of different sizes (1–2nm), although their height is rather small (0.2–0.4nm), which makes the support terrace edges (height of app. 0.3nm) on the left side of the image B visible (Fig. 1B and C). For a smaller amount of segregated K (R K =0.16), the steps are still visible on the image (Fig. 1D). Moreover, on the high resolution image (Fig. 1E), even the [001] oriented rows separated by 0.65nm and characteristic for the bulk terminated TiO2(110)-(1×1) surface can clearly be seen. The characteristic difference between the STM images in Fig. 1B and D is that the bright features on the terraces changed from a dot-like (0D) into a row-like (1D) morphology. Nevertheless, the average corrugation of the surface (the maximal height difference on the image of a certain size) did not change. It is well known that the 1D rows are typical features even on the clean TiO2(110) terraces indicating a slight reduction of the surface; however, in the present case (Fig. 1D and E), the rows possess a rather disordered inner structure, and in some cases, they are not oriented in the [001] direction (left bottom in Fig. 1E). On the basis of these arguments, it can be assumed that the bright 0D and 1D features described above consist mainly of potassium oxides although they may also contain reduced titania species. Continuing the cleaning, we achieved the K segregation level of R K =0.07 (Fig. 1F and G). It can be seen that 1D bright features dominate the terraces. It is known from previous works that two types of added rows can appear on the TiO2(110) surface: a shorter one with a higher z-contrast and a longer one with a lower or even a negative contrast (depending on the tip state) [37]. The shorter rows with a length of 20–30nm can be assigned to the well-known row-like Ti2O3 added phase, and the longer ones with a length of 80–100nm can be identified as Ti defect rows. In the high resolution image (Fig. 1G), it is well appreciable that the bright rows are much more compact than on the image in Fig. 1E, suggesting that in this case, the bright rows are essentially consisting of TiO x phase. It is important to remark that the terrace regions being free of added features possess 1×1 arrangements (Fig. 1E and G). In some cases, we experienced a relatively fast reconstruction of the (1×1) arranged TiO2(110) surface into mixed 1×2 and 1×3 reordering during the cleaning procedure. Accordingly, it was possible to detect segregated potassium also on these reconstructed surfaces. Fig. 2 shows the STM images registered after the ion sputtering and 10min annealing (1050K) on TiO2(110)-(1× n) surfaces containing different amounts of K. At R K =0.22 (Fig. 2A), the image is dominated by the presence of dots (of app. 1.5nm diameter and 0.5nm height) modulated somehow by the periodicity of the underneath oxide row structure. At R K =0.09 (Fig. 2B), the row structure dominates the image; however, some dots are present with an average diameter of 1–2nm. At R K <0.02 (Fig. 2C, under the detection limit), the main feature is the row-like structure typical for the reconstructed TiO2(110) surfaces. These experiments confirm the morphological characteristics of the K-segregated TiO2(110) surfaces: (i) the potassium segregated from the bulk forms added 2D clusters of limited size (both of the diameter and the height) bonded strongly to the support oxide; (ii) where its surface amount is large enough (approximately at R K >0.3), the surface periodicity completely disappears. The segregation of potassium on TiO2(110) was investigated also by LEIS. The Ar+ ion sputtered titania surface was annealed in UHV at increasing temperatures for 10min (Fig. 3 ). LEIS contributions of K and Ti are merged into one peak, referred to as the Ti+K peak, because of the similar masses of these elements. The peak contains negligible contribution of K after ion sputtering at 300K and also after annealing at 500K, because there is no detectable amount of potassium on the surface according to AES. Heating the sample to 700–800K resulted in an enhancement of the O peak, attributable to the inward and outward diffusion of Ti and O ions, respectively. This process tends to restore the stoichiometry of the surface reduced by argon sputtering [40], in accordance with the XPS results presented below. The higher O/Ti atomic ratio is manifested more by the increase in the O LEIS intensity and less by the decrease in the Ti intensity, because the rough sputtered surface gets smoother, which by itself would lead to a general slight increase in the peaks. At 750K, a shift of the Ti+K peak toward smaller kinetic energies sets in, certainly due to the segregation of K to the surface (Fig. 3 inset). At the 760eV primary energy used here, the difference between the peak positions of Ti and K is 26eV [41]. The extent of the shift observed in our case due to annealing at 1000K was 22eV, which is only slightly less. Of course, the O LEIS peak did not shift. The R K Auger ratio measured after the annealing at 1000K was 0.9. To get a more quantitative picture about the different components in the LEIS spectra, peak fitting was performed for the Ti+K region (Fig. 4 A). The peaks in our LEIS spectra correspond to single scattering events, while the baseline and the low-energy tail of the peaks come from multiply scattered and reionized He ions [41]. As the precise shape of the background is not yet known [41], tentatively a Shirley type background is used [42]. The peak shape of the curve obtained after annealing at 500K could be very well fitted with one slightly asymmetric Gauss–Lorentz function (Fig. 4A), assuming that no potassium contribution was present, based on AES results. For the curves obtained after heating to higher temperatures, this peak shape and position were used for Ti. However, for higher temperatures, also an additional component was allowed (K). The results of the fitting procedure are displayed for selected curves in Fig. 4A, while the peak areas for O, K, and Ti are shown in Fig. 4B. Potassium appears on the topmost atomic layer at 750K, and its surface concentration continuously increases up to 1000K. Note that longer annealing times at 1000K did not induce further increase in the amount of potassium according to AES (not shown). The accumulation of potassium in the topmost layer is accompanied by a decrease in the quantity of Ti and O on the surface due to the shadowing effect of K. The segregation of potassium from TiO2 is thermodynamically favored, according to our measurements and the previous work of Herman and Peden [27]. This can be understood by comparing the ionic radii of Ti4+, Ti3+, and K+ (0.68, 0.76 and 1.33Å, respectively) [43]. As regards the location of K within TiO2, the substitution of Ti4+ with K+ does not seem probable because of the large difference in the oxidation states. The incorporation of the large K+ ions at interstitial sites in the TiO2 lattice necessarily induces significant lattice distortion and probably leads to the creation of defect sites. The energy cost of the lattice distortion/defect site formation is recovered during segregation. Note that the opposite effect, the insertion of the alkali ion into titania was observed for lithium, which is a much smaller ion (ion radius 0.68Å) [44]. This makes TiO2 a possible candidate as an electrode material for Li ion batteries. The large size of K+ can be a major reason, why the diffusion of potassium is only measurable in the temperature range, when the diffusion of titanium (and oxygen) also proceeds. 3.1.2 Characterization of the segregated potassium layer In this section, in order to determine the chemical composition of the K containing layer, we analyze the LEIS and XPS signal intensities and peak shapes, taking also account of the morphological characteristics detected by STM. It is important to emphasize that comparing the LEIS peak areas obtained after K segregation at 1000K (Fig. 4B) to the values obtained for 750K, when the coverage of potassium is still very small, it is seen that the decrease in the Ti peak due to K segregation is much larger (72%) than that of the O peak (43%). This is definitely not consistent with a simple view, which would presume a basically unchanged TiO2(110) surface with potassium atoms/ions bound to surface O sites, e.g., in a bridge or hollow configuration [19,20]. In that case, the preferential shadowing and blocking of O sites should have occurred in LEIS and not that of Ti. The structural change induced by K segregation is probably much more complex. Based on the fact that both the Ti and O peaks decreased by ∼50% or more upon K segregation, it can be concluded that K is the most abundant element of the topmost surface layer after annealing at 1000K. This K coverage is characterized in the XPS-LEIS chamber by an AES ratio of R K =0.9. Taking into account that STM measurements indicate the formation of small clusters at 1000K at R K =0.24 (Fig. 1), we may assume a similar morphology, probably with higher cluster density and/or larger cluster sizes after 1000K annealing in the XPS-LEIS chamber. It seems reasonable to presume that K atoms/ions are mostly located in these clusters, while the area in between the clusters is free of potassium, basically consisting of titania. The deposition of Rh provided additional support of this statement (see below). However, it cannot be excluded that the clusters contain also titanium ions. In our previous investigations conducted on potassium-free TiO2(110) crystals, even for nearly stoichiometric titania the O LEIS peak area was always smaller than the Ti peak (app. 90%) at the experimental parameters we use. Taking into account that after annealing at 1000K (R K =0.9) the O LEIS peak was larger than the Ti component (Fig. 4), it can be concluded that a fraction of the O peak is originated from oxygen ions bonded to potassium sites, presumably located on the surface of the clusters. Of course, it is quite reasonable based on chemical grounds to assume that potassium islands contain also oxygen. It was possible to estimate the LEIS sensitivity factors (see Appendix A for details), providing the following main conclusions: (i) there are no significant changes in the neutralization probabilities of He+ ions due to the presence of K. (ii) The potassium containing islands are mostly terminated by K (and possibly by Ti) and not by O. Besides, STM measurements revealed that the thickness of potassium containing clusters is 1–2 atomic layers. Though we could not investigate the subsurface atomic layer of potassium nanodots, it seems reasonable to assume that it is somewhat enriched in O compared with the bulk termination of TiO2(110) surface. Further evidence about preferential potassium/cation termination of the clusters could be obtained by work function measurements (not shown). The segregation of potassium at 1000K induced a 1.7eV decrease in the work function compared with the sputtered surface, calculated from the observed shift in the secondary edge of integral Auger spectra. Note that annealing of the clean sputtered TiO2 without potassium segregation would induce work function change in the opposite direction: the work function of Ar+ sputtered TiO2(110) is smaller than that of the ordered, nearly stoichiometric surface (4.4 and 5.5eV, respectively) [45]. In light of this comparison, the effect of potassium segregation on the work function of our surface is quite significant. In order to understand the segregation of potassium in more detail, as regards the oxidation state and chemical environment, XPS measurements were performed. First, the titania surface sputtered at room temperature was stepwise annealed while monitoring the Ti 2p, O 1s, and K 2p regions (Fig. 5 ). After Ar+ sputtering, the surface region consisted of Ti, O, and a trace amount of K, in accordance with AES. Obviously, a large fraction of Ti ions was found in a reduced state. It is known that ion sputtering preferentially removes oxygen and produces reduced titanium oxide [40]. The positions of the Ti3+ and Ti2+ found in the literature [46,47] for reduced titania are signed in Fig. 5A by dashed lines. Note that the charges in the upper index mean nominal oxidation numbers and not precise real charges. The main O 1s peak was quite asymmetric, which could be attributed to the presence of hydroxyl groups, originated from background H2O. The asymmetry of the O 1s peak was assigned previously also to charge transfers associated with defect formation on TiO2(110) [46]. We prefer the latter assignment, because we never observed any changes in the O 1s peak shape as a function of measurement time. It was described earlier that as an effect of annealing, the stoichiometry of sputtered titania tends to restore due to the inward diffusion of Ti and outward diffusion of O ions [40]. Accordingly, the increase in the temperature led to the dominance of the Ti4+ component in the Ti 2p region, while the O 1s peak became much narrower and more symmetric, both reflecting the presence of less defect sites. Moreover, the K 2p doublet increased significantly from app. 800K. Peak fitting of the Ti 2p region after segregation at 1000K was also performed (Fig. 5D). Symmetric Gauss–Lorentz functions were used and a Shirley baseline [42]. The area of the J =1/2 components was fixed to one half of the area of the J =3/2 components, but the full-width-at-half-maximum (fwhm) was allowed to be different. The plasmon losses of the reduced components were neglected. The peak shape was dominated by Ti4+, with a small contribution of Ti3+, but no Ti2+ component was found. The position of the Ti3+ component was in agreement with previous studies performed on TiO2 samples, in which the difference between Ti4+ and Ti3+ components was ∼1.7eV [46,47]. Notably, the fitting did not show any other spectral components, not characteristic of TiO2 samples. In order to analyze more clearly the top surface region, the Ti 2p region was monitored even at a large take-off angle (θ =71°), for which the information depth is only 34% of its value at θ =16°. However, the peak shape was very similar, only the relative intensity of the Ti3+ component was somewhat larger at θ =71°, indicating a slightly higher concentration of Ti3+ sites near the surface. It is known for potassium that the position of K 2p3/2 peak of the metallic state can be found at higher binding energies (294.4–294.7eV) compared with the same peak of many ionic potassium compounds (292–293eV), like KF, KCl, KBr, etc. It was also demonstrated in various cases that oxidation of adsorbed potassium with oxygen resulted in a decrease in the K 2p3/2 binding energy, such as for K/Ag, K/Pt, and K/Rh [48,49]. Apparently the Madelung potential created by the anions dominates the shift in K core levels during transformation of metallic K into ionic compounds [49]. In the present study, the 2p3/2 peak of segregated K did not shift significantly as a function of temperature and was found at 294.0eV. This value is between those characteristic for metallic and clearly ionic states, indicating that potassium is partially ionized in our case. The lack of metallicity is also suggested by the absence of the strong plasmon loss at ∼300.5eV, characteristic of potassium metal [50]. The partially ionized state of potassium may seem somewhat surprising. In order to understand this observation, one can consider that from LEIS and work function measurements, it was inferred that the KO x islands are largely potassium terminated, and the repulsive interaction among neighboring potassium cations is energetically unfavorable. This can be released by less positive charge on potassium. The partial iconicity of segregated K is suggested also by Auger parameter analysis (see Section 3.2). In an attempt to disclose the chemical nature of the potassium containing structure formed by segregation, literature data about the XPS-binding energies of various potentially relevant compounds, namely K2O, K2O2, K2O3, KO2, and various potassium titanates, were compared with the peak positions obtained in the present work (Appendix A). After all, the potassium containing species formed on TiO2(110) by the segregation of K apparently cannot be unambiguously assigned to any of the bulk compounds by XPS measurements. A surface-specific structure probably formed, with an electronic system/geometry significantly influenced by the presence of the titania surface. This idea is strongly supported by the STM measurements indicating the formation of 1D or 2D nanostructures. 3.2 Effect of potassium on the growth, encapsulation and adsorption properties of rhodium on TiO2(110) The nucleation and growth of rhodium on the potassium-covered TiO2(110) surface (R K =0.9) was first investigated by XPS. The deposition of 0.3, 0.8, and 1.6ML of Rh at room temperature was characterized by Rh 3d5/2 peak positions of 307.2eV, 307.0eV, and 306.9eV, respectively. The observed binding energy shift with increasing coverage is assigned mainly to final state effects due to a more efficient screening in larger Rh clusters [32,51]. The lowest value observed at 1.6ML corresponds to the bulk value [36]. The changes in K 2p, Ti 2p, and O 1s regions observed upon evaporation of 0.8ML of Rh are displayed in Fig. 6 . As expected, a decrease in the peak areas of the titania substrate was found, which was 16% for Ti 2p, and 13% for O 1s. Interestingly, the attenuation of the area of the K 2p doublet was below 1%. This observation indicates a strong preference for Rh nucleation and growth on the K-free fraction of the titania surface instead of the potassium containing clusters, which is supported also by LEIS measurements (see below). On the other hand, the existence of such a big difference in the shadowing of K and Ti by rhodium in XPS is a confirmation of our previous assumption that potassium is not homogeneously distributed on the surface after segregation, but located in specific structures (in the islands observed by STM). Otherwise, the several nm wide Rh clusters should shadow both Ti and K. The deposition of a higher amount (1.6ML) of Rh on the K/TiO2(110) surface led to a measurable decrease also in the K 2p XP doublet, because there was not enough space for rhodium to grow exclusively on the potassium-free areas. The evaporation of Rh on the potassium-covered surface led to a 0.1eV decrease both in the Ti 2p and in the O 1s peak positions, which is assigned to band bending. A much larger shift toward lower binding energies was found for the K 2p doublet (Fig. 7 ). As mentioned above, the ionic compounds of potassium are characterized by lower K 2p3/2 binding energies as compared to K metal, indicating that potassium sites became more cationic upon Rh deposition. As another possible explanation for the downward shift, final state effects could be taken into account. The deposition of rhodium might increase the efficiency of the extra atomic screening of the core hole formed during the photoemission event from the K 2p shell, which would result in a larger kinetic energy of the photoelectron (lower measured binding energy). There are two arguments against the role of screening in the observed binding energy shift. First, apparently there is no direct contact between Rh and the potassium structures up to Θ Rh =0.8ML. The second argument comes from the investigation of the Auger parameter (α′), which is defined as (1) α ′ = E B ( i ) + E K ( jkl ) , where E B(i) is the binding energy of level i, and E K(jkl) is the Auger kinetic energy involving the levels j, k, and l, both referenced to the Fermi level [52,53]. The change in the Auger parameter is known to be an adequate estimate for the change in the relaxation energy, alternatively termed polarization energy (E R): (2) Δ α ′ = 2 Δ E R ( i ) . It provides one of the few experimental procedures for a simple and direct measurement of final state effects (screening). The shift in the polarization energy takes into account the charge transfer in the local valence orbital of the core-ionized atom and the contribution to the electronic relaxation energy of all the other atoms in the system. The Auger parameter analysis is usually performed with core level binding energies and with Auger transitions involving only core levels. However, it is applicable also with core-valence-valence Auger transitions, if the valence levels are atomic like (i.e. localized) [53]. Here, the K 2p3/2 photoemission peak and the L2M23M23 1D Auger peak were used. After K segregation at 1000K (R K =0.9), the Auger parameter was α′=545.9eV, which is between literature data for bulk metallic K and values for ionic compounds, such as KBr, KF (547.9, 543.8, 542.6eV, respectively) [54]. Both the partial ionicity of the potassium containing clusters and their small size lead to a decreased screening resulting in the lower value of α′ compared with the value obtained for metallic potassium. Upon the deposition of 0.8ML of Rh, the change in the Auger parameter was Δα′=−0.25eV, indicating a slightly smaller relaxation energy, ruling out the possible screening effect of Rh in relation to K. Consequently, the observed Rh induced downward shift in the K 2p region is an initial state effect, leading to more cationic potassium sites. Accordingly, the slight decrease in α’ may occur due to the lower population of K 4s-derived states leading to less screening of the K 2p core hole by valence electrons. This charge transfer is interesting, because up to a relatively high Rh coverage (0.8ML), there is no shadowing of potassium by rhodium, suggesting the lack of direct contact between Rh clusters and potassium islands. Moreover, the downward shift of K 2p3/2 is well measurable even at significantly lower Rh coverages (0.3eV at 0.3ML). We propose an indirect effect of Rh on the charge state of K, as follows: Rh clusters grown on titania represent a Schottky contact, implying that electrons will flow from the titania substrate to Rh clusters till the Fermi levels are equilibrated [12]. Since the mobile charge carrier density in TiO2(110) is not high, this results in the formation of a positive space charge region in titania. This process leads to the partial depletion of the Ti3d band gap states and to a preferential decrease in the Ti3+ component compared with Ti4+, which was observed also in our case upon Rh deposition. The radius of the depletion region around metal clusters was reported [12] to be in the range of 10–100nm, which is larger than the average distance among neighboring potassium islands (Fig. 1C). In turn, this positive charge facilitates the electron transfer from the partially cationic potassium sites to TiO2. The existence of negatively charged Rh nanoparticles in the vicinity of K containing clusters probably stabilizes the positive charge on K. Since the Ti3+/Ti4+ ratio decreased in our case upon evaporation of Rh, the electrons transferred from K were probably not accumulated finally in TiO2, but on Rh clusters. Note that as a general rule, the amount of charge transferred during Schottky contact formation increases with increasing mobile charge carrier density in the semiconductor [12]. Since the islands, containing initially partially ionized K, can be considered electron donors, these islands also increase the number of mobile electrons in TiO2 near the surface, which in turn leads to a larger number of electrons transferred to Rh nanoparticles compared with the potassium-free surface. Moreover, as mentioned above, the segregation of potassium results in a decrease in the work function, which again leads to an increased electron transfer to Rh. The factors considered here in relation to the electron transfer from K are of course interconnected. The nucleation of Rh clusters on the potassium-covered titania surface was investigated also by LEIS. The deposition of 0.5ML of Rh near room temperature on the K/TiO2(110) surface (R K =0.7), obtained by 5-min annealing at 1000K, led to the diminution of both the O and the Ti+K LEIS peaks (Fig. 8 A). However, the Ti+K peak decreased asymmetrically: the reduction of its intensity was sharper on its high energy side implying more shadowing of the Ti component compared with the K component. For a more quantitative analysis, peak fitting was performed in the way described in Section 3.1. The deposition of rhodium did not induce any reduction of the K peak (Fig. 8B), while the attenuation of the Ti peak was rather strong (45%). This result definitely confirms that there is a very strong preference for the rhodium clusters to nucleate and grow on titania and not on the potassium structures. Since during evaporation a part of Rh atoms are landed on top of the potassium islands, this observation clearly indicates that the driving force for direct Rh–K bonding is very weak. One might assume that Rh clusters could nucleate also on the potassium structures and be accompanied by the migration of K ions on top of rhodium nanoparticles. This process would have also resulted in the lack of shadowing of potassium by rhodium both in XPS and LEIS. To crosscheck for this possibility, the K/TiO2(110)+0.5MLRh surface was continuously sputtered by He+ ions, and the temporal evolution of the Rh LEIS peak was monitored. In case a potassium overlayer existed on top of Rh crystallites after evaporation, first this potassium layer would be sputtered away and Rh atoms below these potassium sites would become detectable by LEIS, resulting in an increase or at least in a milder decrease in the Rh LEIS intensity in the first phase of sputtering. Our previous investigations performed on a potassium-free TiO2(110) surface covered by Rh or Au in the submonolayer coverage range showed that the LEIS signal of metal clusters decreases exponentially as a function of He+ ion dose. If a potassium overlayer was formed on Rh clusters in the present case, a deviation from the linear decrease would arise on a logarithmic scale. However, Rh signal attenuated in a linear fashion (i.e. exponentially) proving the lack of potassium migration on top of Rh clusters (Fig. 8A inset). Note that the migration of a TiO x layer on rhodium nanoparticles could be easily demonstrated in a similar way (see below). In order to investigate the thermal behavior, by LEIS, Rh was deposited (1.6ML) at 330K on the K/TiO2(110) surface (R K =0.9), followed by annealing at higher temperatures for 10min (Fig. 9 ). The Rh intensity decreased very steeply from ∼520K, and the Rh peak almost completely disappeared at 800K, accompanied by an increase in the O and Ti+K peaks. Since the intensity of the Rh3d XP doublet decreased only slightly up to this temperature range (Fig. 6), this phenomenon can clearly be assigned to the encapsulation of Rh nanoparticles by a titanium oxide layer, as was previously observed for Rh on TiO2(110) [32,34]. Note that the Rh LEIS peak reappeared after bombardment by He+ ions (inset of Fig. 10 ). The second notable change induced by thermal treatments was a shift and a broadening of the Ti+K peak toward higher energies, indicating an enhanced Ti/K atomic ratio on the topmost layer. Peak fitting of the spectrum obtained after annealing at 800K yielded a Ti/K peak area ratio of ∼1.3 at Θ Rh =1.6ML. Moreover, the higher the amount of Rh was the larger shift was observed (inset of Fig. 9). This finding clearly indicates that preferentially Ti (and O) and not K ions migrate onto Rh crystallites, because at increasing Rh coverages, the composition of the encapsulating layer contributes more and more significantly to the LEIS spectrum obtained at 800K. We observed a 80% decrease in the intensity of the Ti+K LEIS peak after evaporation of 8ML of Rh at room temperature. Taking into account that a subsequent annealing at 800K probably results in significant agglomeration of Rh clusters, it is understandable, why the LEIS spectrum is not completely dominated by the constituents of the encapsulating layer (Ti and O) after annealing the 8ML Rh+K/TiO2 surface at 800 K. An important question is, whether the presence of potassium promotes the encapsulation of Rh by TiO x or not. For comparison, the LEIS annealing experiment was performed after evaporation of 1.6ML of Rh also on the potassium-free ion sputtered TiO2(110) surface. The encapsulation proceeded at temperatures lower by cca 100K in case of the ion sputtered surface, as shown in Fig. 10. It is known that the encapsulation of Rh on rutile TiO2(110) in UHV depends on the extent of reduction of the crystal. It did not proceed up to 800K on a rather new, almost completely stoichiometric crystal [31], while for more O-deficient samples, the temperature at which the metal LEIS signal decreased to one half of its original value due to encapsulation was found in the broad range of 500–760K [32,34]. In the present case, this temperature was 600K for the K/TiO2 surface (Fig. 10), which can be considered typical. In this sense, seemingly the presence of potassium did not have a dramatic effect on the encapsulation, but some influence of K cannot be excluded. The measurement about the encapsulation on the sputtered surface is not really a suitable reference to decide about it, because the sputtering itself has a promoting effect on the encapsulation [31]. Considering the complexity and the sensitivity of the formation of a TiO x decoration layer on top of the Rh crystallites at high temperatures, we checked the structure of the decoration layer in the presence of potassium. For this investigation, we used a sample, which exhibited much more steps than presented above in Fig. 1 (see Fig. 11 A). As it was mentioned before, this type of surface was more difficult to clean than those having extremely large terraces of approximately 50×50nm2. The surface before the exposition of Rh at room temperature contained potassium (obtained by segregation) corresponding to a relative Auger ratio of R K =0.16 and its terraces exhibited characteristically a (1×4) reconstruction. Following the deposition of 10ML of Rh at 300K, the surface was annealed at 1050K for 10min. Large, hexagonal, approximately 30 layers thick Rh particles formed in this way and because of their flat top facets, it was possible to obtain atomically resolved images on them (Fig. 11B). The insert image of 5×3nm2 in top right of the image, recorded in constant height mode, shows a so-called “wheel”-type TiO x decoration layer described in our previous work [55]. Since this overlayer structure can be identified with one found on top of Rh crystallites formed on a clean TiO2(110)-(1×1) surface, it seems clear that the segregated potassium is not incorporated into the encapsulation layer. Only a slight systematic difference was observed, namely the Rh particles were growing in a relatively high ratio in a direction deviating from [001] orientation of the TiO2(110) surface (Fig. 11B). Similarly, on another surface, containing Ti, O, and an electropositive element namely on SrTiO3(001), it was found that the encapsulating layer on top of Pd nanoclusters does not contain the electropositive element, only Ti and O [56]. From the catalytic point of view, a question of outmost importance is whether the presence of the potassium structure induces changes in adsorption properties. To check this, the adsorption–desorption behavior of a well-known probe molecule, carbon monoxide was investigated by TDS. The adsorption of CO in the presence of potassium was thoroughly investigated previously on transition metal surfaces [4,5,9]. Alkali metal additives, including potassium, have a stabilizing effect, leading to a broadening of molecular CO desorption toward higher temperatures. At relatively high potassium coverages, approaching the saturation of the first K layer, desorption of CO and potassium occurs simultaneously in a distinct desorption state at ∼700K, indicating the formation of a K–CO surface complex at higher K doses. The amount of adsorbed CO decreases with increasing potassium coverage. The interaction of CO with metal nanoparticles on oxide single crystals/films was also studied. With increasing cluster sizes, the broadening of the molecular CO TPD peak was observed toward lower temperatures both on platinum [57] and rhodium [58] supported by TiO2(110). Analogously, CO desorption occurred mostly from step sites at ∼450K at small Pt crystal sizes (d <3nm) on SiO2, while at larger diameters, the contribution of desorption from terrace sites (∼350K) gave the largest TDS peak [59]. In the case of Rh on TiO2, dissociative adsorption was much more pronounced compared with Pt, and the participation of lattice O in the reoxidation of atomic carbon at ∼800K was demonstrated [58,60]. Thermal desorption spectroscopy was performed in the present study both on the potassium-free ion sputtered surface and on the surface covered by potassium (R K =0.9) segregated at 1000K. Different amounts of Rh were deposited on these surfaces at 300K, followed by saturation with CO at 190K. Apparently no CO adsorption took place on the Rh-free surfaces in the temperature range under investigation. On Rh-covered surfaces, CO desorption was observed in two peaks, with maxima at ∼450K and 830–945K (Fig. 12 ). Based on the literature data summarized above, the former one can be assigned to molecular, while the high temperature one to dissociative adsorption. No CO2 formation was found, indicative of the absence of disproportionation. At each Rh coverages the TDS peak corresponding to molecular adsorption was broadened toward higher temperatures and even intensified on the K containing surfaces compared to the K-free case (Fig. 12C). This observation clearly indicates a stabilization effect of K in relation to CO bound to Rh. The difference in the high temperature edges of the molecular adsorption peaks was ∼40K at Θ Rh =0.3–0.7ML, while it was ∼60K at Θ Rh =2ML. This effect cannot be assigned to differences in the Rh cluster size, because that parameter influences the low temperature part of this TDS peak, as it was pointed out in the literature survey. No K desorption was detected in parallel with CO molecular desorption. The observed stabilizing effect of K on our surface resembles what was found on Pt metals at low K coverages, when no K–CO surface complex was formed. The lack of the K–CO surface complex formation is of course not surprising at Θ Rh =0.3–0.7ML, since K is not located on Rh clusters. At Θ Rh =2ML, according to XPS data presented above, there is a direct contact between a part of K and Rh, but potassium is probably located in between Rh clusters and titania substrate. The interesting point is that the partially oxidized K structure can influence the binding of CO on the Rh clusters even in the absence of a direct contact between Rh and K. This is very probably related to the indirect electron transfer from potassium to the substrate, which was observed by XPS upon Rh deposition, because it probably leads to an increase in the electron density on Rh clusters itself. 4 Conclusions The segregation of potassium was investigated on the TiO2(110) surface by means of STM, LEIS, and XPS. The migration of K from the bulk of titania crystals to the surface started at 750–800K, which is the temperature range, where the bulk diffusion of O (and Ti) ions becomes significant. This coincidence suggests that the mobility of O and Ti ions is a prerequisite for the diffusion of bulky K ions. Segregated potassium formed small clusters of 1–2nm, containing also oxygen. These clusters were preferentially cation terminated and located more on the one-dimensional defect sites (Ti2O3 strings) of the (1×1) rutile surface and on the Ti2O3 rows of the (1× n) reconstructed surfaces. According to XPS studies, the potassium on the surface after segregation at 1000K was only partially ionized, and the Ti 2p region was dominated by the nominally Ti4+ component. Although Ti3+ gave a small contribution, Ti2+ was not present. During deposition of Rh on the K/TiO2(110) surface, a very clear preference was observed for the metal clusters to nucleate and grow not on the potassium structures, but on the remaining K-free regions of titania surface up to relatively large Rh coverages (0.8ML). This finding suggests a very weak driving force for direct rhodium–potassium bonding on the titania surface. In spite of this, evaporation of Rh on K/TiO2(110) induced a charge transfer from K through TiO2 to Rh. The encapsulation of Rh nanoparticles, a well-known phenomenon on TiO2, proceeded also in the presence of potassium. The decoration layer on the Rh clusters did not contain potassium, only Ti and O. At large Rh cluster sizes, the wheel-like structure of the cover layer could be identified with one found on top of Rh crystallites formed on the clean TiO2(110)-(1×1) surface. According to TDS studies, the presence of potassium exerted a stabilization effect for CO on Rh nanoparticles, which is attributed to the indirect electron transfer (long range effect) from potassium structures to Rh. coredata.dc:description: In order to understand the promoting mechanism of alkali additives, we have studied potassium overlayers on TiO2(110). The surface was prepared by thermal segregation of K from the bulk to the surface above 750–800K. The bulk diffusion of the Ti/O ions is required for the migration of large K ions inside the lattice. STM and LEIS revealed that segregated potassium forms small clusters of 1–2nm on the surface, containing also oxygen. These clusters are located preferentially on the one-dimensional defect sites (Ti2O3 strings) of the (1×1) rutile surface and on the Ti2O3 rows of the (1× n) reconstructed surfaces. According to XPS, the potassium on the surface after segregation at 1000K is only partially ionized and the Ti 2p region is dominated by the Ti4+ component. XPS and LEIS provided evidence of a very clear preference for the Rh clusters to grow near 300K not on the potassium structures but on the potassium-free parts of titania surface. This finding may imply the absence of a direct contact between Rh and K at low Rh coverages. Nevertheless, evaporation of Rh on K/TiO2(110) results in more cationic K sites, due to an electron transfer from K to Rh through titania. The decoration and encapsulation of Rh nanoparticles by TiO x proceed also in the presence of potassium. The capping layer does not contain potassium. At large Rh cluster sizes, the wheel-like structure of the cover layer could be identified with a structure found on top of Rh crystallites formed on the K-free titania surface. The presence of potassium stabilized CO on Rh nanoparticles, which is attributed to the indirect charge transfer from potassium structures to rhodium (long range effect).
coredata.dc:title: Segregation of K and its effects on the growth, decoration, and adsorption properties of Rh nanoparticles on TiO2(110)
